questions.question: A man walks 1km due east and then 1km due north. His displacement is _____.
A tugboat has a resultant velocity of 20 knots. If the river flows at 12 knots, the boat's direction relative to flow is _____.
Two perpendicular forces (12N and 5N) act on a 5kg mass. The acceleration along the resultant is _____.
A ball moves at 18 m/s, 60° to horizontal. Its horizontal velocity component is _____.
Two 10N forces act north and east. The resultant is _____.
A person moves 20m north, 12m east, and 15m south. Displacement from start is _____.
An aircraft flies 300km 30° west of north, then 400km 60° east of north. Resultant displacement is _____.
Two forces (12N and 5N) have a 13N resultant. The angle between them is _____.
A boat moves east at 40 m/s with a 30 m/s current. Resultant speed is _____.
Two forces (4N and 6N) act on a point. Their resultant is 2√13N. The resultant's direction is _____.
A car accelerates from rest at 2 m/s². What is its velocity after 5 seconds?
questions.explanation: Using v = u + at → v = 0 + (2)(5) = 10 m/s.

questions.question: An air force jet flying with a speed of 335 m/s went past an anti-aircraft gun. How far is the aircraft 5 s later when the gun was fired? (1978:Q3)
questions.explanation: At constant speed s = vt → s = 335 × 5 = 1675 m.

questions.question: A palm fruit dropped to the ground from the top of a tree 45 m tall. How long does it take to reach the ground? (g = 10 m/s²) (1978:Q4)

The velocity–time graph of a car shows it accelerates uniformly at 3 m/s² for 5 s, then maintains that velocity for 1 minute, and finally decelerates to rest in 3 s. Calculate the total distance covered. (1979:Q49)
questions.explanation: v after 5 s = 3×5 = 15 m/s. Areas: triangle ½×5×15 = 37.5 m; rectangle 15×60 = 900 m; final triangle ½×3×15 = 22.5 m. Total = 37.5+900+22.5 = 960 m.

questions.question: The motion of the moving skin of a talking drum can rightly be described as: (1980:Q12)
questions.explanation: The drum skin vibrates to-and-fro: oscillatory motion.

questions.question: What is the acceleration of a particle whose motion is represented on a velocity–time graph? (1980:Q23)
questions.explanation: Acceleration = slope of v–t graph. Using the points given yields ≈0.67 m/s².

questions.question: A motor car of total mass 800 kg is travelling at 20 m/s when the driver suddenly observes a stationary dog 50 m ahead. If the car’s brakes can exert a force of 2000 N, what will most likely happen? (1981:Q25)
options: The car will be able to stop immediately the driver notices the dog
The car will stop 30 m after hitting the dog
The car will stop 20 m in front of the dog
The driver will quickly reverse the car
The car will stop 5 m beyond the dog
questions.explanation: Braking deceleration a = −F/m = −2000/800 = −2.5 m/s². Stopping distance from v² = u² + 2as: 0 = 20² + 2(−2.5)s ⇒ s = 80 m. Dog is 50 m away → car travels 80 m, so it hits the dog and stops 30 m beyond it.

questions.question: A body falls freely from a height of 40 m onto the top of a platform 0.8 m above the ground. Its velocity on reaching the platform is: (g = 9.8 m/s²) (1981:Q33)
questions.explanation: Effective fall distance s = 40 − 0.8 = 39.2 m. v² = 2gs ⇒ v = √(2×9.8×39.2) ≈ 27.7 m/s.

questions.question: Two particles X and Y start from rest and cover the same distance. The acceleration of X is twice that of Y. What is the ratio of the time taken by X to that taken by Y? (1981:Q35)
questions.explanation: s = ½at² (u=0). Equal s ⇒ a_X t_X² = a_Y t_Y². With a_X = 2a_Y ⇒ 2 t_X² = t_Y² ⇒ t_X/t_Y = 1/√2.

questions.question: Two taxis leave Benin and Agbor (80 km apart) at 12:00 hr. From the given distance–time graph, the distance of their meeting point P from Benin and the meeting time are: (1982:Q12)
questions.explanation: By tracing intersections on the provided graph the meeting point is 29 km from Benin at 13:15 hr.

questions.question: A mango fruit drops from a branch 10 m above the ground. Just before hitting the ground its velocity is (g = 10 m/s²): (1982:Q13)
Which of the following statements is true of a body which is moving in a straight line with uniform acceleration? The velocity of the body:
options: must always be zero when the body stops accelerating
will increase with time in the direction of the acceleration
is equal to the quotient of distance travelled and time
is the product of the distance travelled and time
questions.explanation: With uniform acceleration, velocity changes at a constant rate; it increases with time in the direction of the acceleration.

questions.question: A train has an initial velocity of 44 m/s and an acceleration of −4 m/s². Its velocity after 10 seconds is: (1983:Q15)
The distance travelled by a particle starting from rest is plotted against the square of the time elapsed. The resulting graph is linear. The slope of this graph is a measure of:
questions.explanation: s = ½ a t² (u=0). Plotting s versus t² gives slope = ½ a.

questions.question: Which of the following types of motion are oscillatory? I. A diving board when used by a diver. II. The motion of the balance wheel of a wristwatch. III. The motion of the turn-table of a record player. IV. The motion of the center of a ten kobo piece as it rolls down an inclined plane. V. The motion of the needle of a D.C. ammeter into which a low A.C. current is passed. (1985:Q4)
questions.explanation: I (diving board) and II (balance wheel) perform to-and-fro oscillatory motion. Turn-table and rolling coin are rotational/translational, not oscillatory.

questions.question: The graph above describes the motion of a particle. The acceleration of the particle during the motion is: (1985:Q?)
If a car starts from rest and moves with a uniform acceleration of 10 m/s² for ten seconds, the distance it covers in the last one second of the motion is: (1985:Q6)
Two objects, one having three times the mass of the other, are dropped at the same time from a tall building. When they are above the ground, the two objects will have the same: (1986:Q5)
questions.explanation: Neglecting air resistance, all bodies fall with the same acceleration g regardless of mass.

questions.question: The velocity-time graph above describes the motion of a particle between two points P and Q. What is the distance between P and Q? (1987:Q3)
questions.explanation: Break into shapes: triangle (½×1×4)=2 m; trapezium ½(4+6)×1=5 m; rectangle 6×1.5=9 m; trapezium ½(2+6)×0.5=2 m. Total = 18 m.

questions.question: A particle starts from rest and moves with a constant acceleration of 0.5 m/s². The distance covered by the particle in 10 s is: (1988:Q6)
The figure shows displacement–time graphs for three motions. Which statement is correct? (1988:Q9)
options: Graph 2 corresponds to the highest velocity
Graph 3 corresponds to a particle moving in the negative x direction
Graph 2 corresponds to a particle moving in the positive x direction
questions.explanation: Velocity is slope (Δx/Δt). If Graph 1 has zero slope throughout, the particle is stationary (v = 0).

questions.question: Two points on a velocity–time graph have coordinates (5 s, 10 m/s) and (20 s, 20 m/s). Calculate the mean acceleration between the two points. (1989:Q3)
Which graph represents motion with uniform velocity? (Conceptual)
options: A velocity–time graph with a straight positive slope
A velocity–time graph parallel to the t-axis
questions.explanation: Uniform velocity ⇒ acceleration = 0 ⇒ v constant ⇒ velocity–time graph is horizontal (parallel to t-axis).

questions.question: A car moving at 90 km/h is brought uniformly to rest by brakes in 10 s. How far did the car travel after the brakes were applied? (1990:Q6)
questions.explanation: 90 km/h = 25 m/s. Average velocity during deceleration = (25 + 0)/2 = 12.5 m/s. Distance = 12.5 × 10 = 125 m.

questions.question: What is the average velocity of the sprinter whose velocity–time graph is shown? (options: A. 85.0 m/s, B. 17.0 m/s, C. 8.5 m/s).
questions.explanation: Total distance from graph = 80 m, total time = 10 s ⇒ average velocity = 80/10 = 8.0 m/s. None of the provided options match.

questions.question: A body starts from rest and moves with uniform acceleration of 6 m/s². What distance does it cover in the third second? (1992:Q4)
questions.explanation: S₂ = ½×6×2² = 12 m; S₃ = ½×6×3² = 27 m; distance in third second = 27 − 12 = 15 m.

questions.question: The diagram shows a v–t graph of a car. Find the total distance covered during acceleration and the next interval. (1993:Q3)
questions.explanation: Stage 1 area = ½×10×10 = 50 m. Stage 2 area (given) = 25 m. Total = 75 m.

questions.question: An aeroplane lands at 180 km/h and is brought to rest uniformly in 30 s. What distance does it cover on the runway before stopping? (1993:Q5)
questions.explanation: 180 km/h = 50 m/s. Average speed = (50 + 0)/2 = 25 m/s. Distance = 25 × 30 = 750 m.

questions.question: A motor vehicle is brought to rest from speed 15 m/s in 20 s. Calculate the retardation. (1994:Q5)
When a ball rolls on a smooth level ground, the motion of its centre is: (1995:Q5)
questions.explanation: The centre-of-mass moves in translational motion while the ball also rotates about its center.

questions.question: The velocity–time graph of a body moving in a straight line and decelerating uniformly to rest is represented by: (1995:Q6)
questions.explanation: Uniform deceleration gives a straight line with negative slope on a v–t graph.

questions.question: The distance x (m) traveled by a particle in time t is x = 10 + 12t². Find the average speed between t = 2 s and t = 5 s. (1997:Q2)
questions.explanation: x(2)=10+12×4=58 m; x(5)=10+12×25=310 m; Δx=252 m; Δt=3 s ⇒ average speed = 252/3 = 84 m/s. (Note: based on the provided formula the correct average is 84 m/s — choose accordingly.)

questions.question: In free fall, a body of mass 1 kg drops from height 125 m in 5 s. How long will a 2 kg body take to fall from same height? (g = 10 m/s²) (1998:Q4)
questions.explanation: Neglecting air resistance, fall time is independent of mass; both take 5 s.

questions.question: The velocity v of a particle is given by v = 10 + 2t². Find instantaneous acceleration after 5 s. (2000:Q8)
questions.explanation: a = dv/dt = 4t. At t=5 s, a = 4×5 = 20 m/s².

questions.question: An autonomous motorcycle travelling at 30 m/s starts to apply its brakes when it is 50 m from a traffic light that has just turned red. If it just reaches the traffic light, its deceleration is: (2005:Q28)
questions.explanation: Use v² = u² + 2as with v=0, u=30 m/s, s=50 m ⇒ 0 = 900 + 2a(50) ⇒ a = −9 m/s² (retardation 9 m/s²).

questions.question: The motion of smoke particles from a chimney is typical of: (2006:Q13)
What is the acceleration between two points on a velocity–time graph with coordinates (10 s, 15 m/s) and (20 s, 35 m/s)? (2009:Q4)
A car accelerates uniformly from rest at 4 m/s². How far will it travel in the fifth complete second? (2009:Q5)
From the velocity–time graph (points E–F–G–H), which statement is true? (2010:Q3)
options: The car decelerates between F and H
The car accelerates between F and G
The car has a constant speed between E and F
The car has no acceleration between F and G
questions.explanation: Between F and G the graph is horizontal ⇒ speed constant ⇒ acceleration zero.

questions.question: A stone and a feather are dropped from the same height above the earth’s surface. Ignoring air resistance, which is correct? (2010:Q4)
options: Both reach the ground at the same time
The feather is blown away while stone drops steadily
questions.explanation: In vacuum (no air resistance), all bodies fall with the same acceleration g.

questions.question: A car moves with an initial velocity of 25 m/s and reaches 45 m/s in 10 s. What is its acceleration? (2010:Q5)
If it takes an object 3 s to fall freely to the ground from a certain height, what distance is covered? (2011:Q7)
From the velocity–time graph shown, which quantity CANNOT be determined? (2012:Q5)
questions.explanation: The graph shows no initial acceleration segment; initial acceleration cannot be obtained.

questions.question: Calculate the total distance covered by a train before coming to rest if its initial speed is 30 m/s with a constant retardation of 0.1 m/s². (2012:Q6)
questions.explanation: Use v² = u² + 2as with v=0 ⇒ s = −u²/(2a) = 900/(0.2) = 4500 m.

questions.question: A car starts from rest and moves with a uniform acceleration of 30 m/s² for 20 s. Calculate the distance covered. (2012:Q7)
A train with initial velocity 20 m/s is subjected to a uniform deceleration of 2 m/s². Time required to come to a halt is: (2013:Q6)
Which type of motion do the wheels of a moving car undergo? (2014:Q5)
questions.explanation: The wheel’s center translates while the wheel rotates about its axis.

questions.question: From the diagram provided, the region of zero acceleration is: (2014:Q6)
questions.explanation: NS is horizontal on the v–t graph ⇒ zero acceleration.

questions.question: A body starts from rest and accelerates uniformly at 3 m/s². Its velocity after travelling a distance of 24 m is: (2014:Q7)
Which velocity–time graph shows uniform acceleration of a body from rest? (2015:Q26)
questions.explanation: Uniform acceleration from rest is a straight line through the origin with positive slope.

questions.question: A train with initial velocity 20 m/s is subjected to uniform deceleration of 2 m/s². The time required to bring the train to a complete halt is: (2015:Q50)
A car has an initial velocity of 40 m/s and retards at 3 m/s². Calculate its velocity after 10 s. (2015:Q48)
A body moving at 20 m/s decelerates uniformly at 5 m/s² until its speed becomes 10 m/s. The distance covered within this period is: (2017:Q17)
A projectile is fired horizontally with a velocity of 98 ms⁻¹ from the top of a tower 490 m high. Calculate the time it takes to hit the ground.
questions.explanation: Time to fall depends only on vertical motion. Using s = ½gt², with s = 490 m and g = 9.8 ms⁻²: 490 = 0.5 × 9.8 × t² → t² = 100 → t = 10 s.

questions.question: A ball is projected horizontally from the top of a tower with a velocity of 20 ms⁻¹. If it lands 45 m away from the foot of the tower, calculate the height of the tower.
questions.explanation: Horizontal time = distance / velocity = 45 ÷ 20 = 2.25 s. Vertical displacement = ½gt² = 0.5 × 9.8 × (2.25)² ≈ 25 m.

questions.question: A bullet is fired horizontally from a gun with a speed of 500 m/s from a cliff 78.4 m high. How far from the foot of the cliff will the bullet strike the ground?
questions.explanation: Time to fall = √(2h/g) = √(2 × 78.4 ÷ 9.8) = 4 s. Horizontal distance = velocity × time = 500 × 4 = 2000 m.

questions.question: A stone is thrown horizontally from the top of a building 45 m high with a speed of 20 m/s. Find the horizontal distance covered before hitting the ground.
questions.explanation: Time to fall = √(2h/g) = √(90 ÷ 9.8) ≈ 3.03 s. Horizontal distance = velocity × time = 20 × 3.03 ≈ 60.6 m ≈ 60 m.

questions.question: An object is projected horizontally from a height of 80 m with a velocity of 40 m/s. Find the horizontal distance covered before it strikes the ground.
questions.explanation: Time to fall = √(2h/g) = √(160 ÷ 9.8) ≈ 4.04 s. Horizontal distance = 40 × 4.04 ≈ 161.6 m ≈ 160 m.

questions.question: A football is hit with a velocity of 6 m/s at an angle of 30° to the horizontal. The time of flight of the ball is: (2016:Q43)
A stone is projected with a velocity of 20 m/s at an angle of 30° above the horizontal. Calculate the maximum height attained. (2014:Q28)
A projectile is launched with a velocity of 40 m/s at an angle of 30° to the horizontal. Find the maximum height reached. (Take g = 10 m/s²)
questions.explanation: Vertical component = 40 sin30° = 20 m/s. Maximum height = u²sin²θ / (2g) = 20² / 20 = 20 m.

questions.question: A ball is thrown horizontally with a velocity of 25 m/s from the top of a tower 45 m high. Calculate the time taken to reach the ground. (g = 10 m/s²)
questions.explanation: Vertical motion: h = 1/2gt² → 45 = 5t² → t² = 9 → t = 3 s.

questions.question: A body is projected with a velocity of 50 m/s at an angle of 37° with the horizontal. Calculate the time of flight. (Take g = 10 m/s², sin37° = 0.6)
questions.explanation: Time of flight = 2u sinθ / g = 2 × 50 × 0.6 / 10 = 6 s.

questions.question: A particle is projected with a velocity of 20 m/s at an angle of 45° to the horizontal. Find the range. (g = 10 m/s²)
Which of the following is a correct explanation of the inertia of a body?
options: Ability to overcome the earth's gravity
Reluctance to start moving and its readiness to stop moving once it has begun to move
Reluctance to start moving and its reluctance to stop moving once it has begun to move
questions.explanation: Inertia is the resistance to changes in motion (1st Law). Option E correctly describes both aspects: resistance to starting and stopping motion.

questions.question: If the total force acting on a particle is zero, the linear momentum will
questions.explanation: Newton's 1st Law: When net force is zero, momentum remains constant (no acceleration).

questions.question: A man standing on a lift that is descending does not feel any weight because
options: There is no reaction from the floor of the lift
There is no gravitational pull on the man in the lift
The inside of the lift is airtight
questions.explanation: During free-fall (a=g), the normal reaction force from the floor becomes zero, making the man feel weightless (1st Law - inertia).

questions.question: The tendency of a body to remain at rest when a force is applied to it is called
questions.explanation: This is the definition of inertia - the resistance to changes in motion (Newton's 1st Law).

questions.question: A man stands on a spring scale placed in a lift. The lift descends at constant velocity. As a result, the scale reads a weight
options: Greater than the weight of the man
The same as the weight of the man
Less than the weight of the man
Greater than the weight of the man by 1kg
questions.explanation: Constant velocity means a=0 → F_net=0. Scale shows normal force (T) which equals weight when a=0 (F=ma).

questions.question: A body of mass 10kg on a smooth inclined plane is connected over a smooth pulley to a mass of 15kg. The acceleration of the system is
A force of 16N applied to a 4.0kg block at rest on a smooth horizontal surface. What is the velocity of the block at t=5 seconds?
A constant force F acts on a 0.04kg object initially at rest. If the speed is 500m/s after moving 50m, what is F?
A 1000kg elevator descending with acceleration 1.0m/s² (g=10m/s²). The tension in the cable is
An elevator of mass 4800kg is supported by a cable with max tension 60,000N. The maximum upward acceleration is
A 5kg block released on a smooth plane inclined at 30°. Its acceleration is
A 2kg body moving vertically has velocity increase from 10m/s to 40m/s in 4s. The upward force is
A rope pulls a 10kg mass vertically up from rest to 4m/s in 8s. The tension is
An 80N body in an elevator moving up at 5m/s². Force from floor is
A 100N force kicks a 0.8kg ball for 0.8s. Final velocity is
Force needed to give 60kg mass 10m/s² upward acceleration (g=10m/s²) is
A rocket burns 0.01kg of fuel each second and ejects it as a gas with velocity of 5000m/s. What force does the gas exert on the rocket?
questions.explanation: Thrust = (dm/dt) × v = 0.01 × 5000 = 50N (3rd Law: Equal and opposite reaction force on rocket)

questions.question: A jet engine develops thrust of 270Ns when exhaust velocity is 300m/s. Mass ejected per second is
A rocket burns fuel at 10kg/s and ejects it at 5×10³m/s. The thrust is
Which demonstrates Newton's Third Law? I. Jet aircraft II. Rocket propulsion III. Gun recoil IV. Walking
questions.explanation: All involve action-reaction pairs: exhaust gases/jet (I,II), bullet/gun (III), foot/ground (IV)

questions.question: A 5.0kg ball hits a wall at 2m/s and rebounds. The impulse on the wall is
questions.explanation: Impulse = Δp = m(v-u) = 5(2-(-2)) = 20kgm/s (Wall exerts equal & opposite force)

questions.question: A machine gun with a mass of 5kg fires a 50g bullet at a speed of 100m/s. The recoil speed of the machine gun is
questions.explanation: Conservation: m₁v₁ + m₂v₂ = 0 → (5)v + (0.05)(100) = 0 → v = -1 m/s (negative indicates opposite direction)

questions.question: A gun of mass 2.0kg fires a bullet of mass 1.6×10⁻²kg due east at 150m/s. The recoil velocity of the gun is
A 0.05kg bullet traveling at 500m/s penetrates a wall 0.25m. Average resisting force is
A footballer applies 30N force for 0.05s to a 0.075kg ball. Final speed is
A particle of mass M at rest splits into two pieces (m and M-m). If one piece has velocity v, the other has
A 100g body moving at 10m/s collides with a wall and rebounds at 2m/s. Change in momentum is
A 0.1kg arrow at 15m/s embeds in a 0.4kg block at rest. Their common velocity is
A 0.15kg ball hits a wall at 50m/s and rebounds at 30m/s. The impulse on the wall is
A 0.025kg bullet penetrates 0.15m into wood with average resisting force 7.5×10³N. Initial speed was
A 0.05kg bullet at 200m/s embeds in a 0.95kg block. Final kinetic energy is
A 12kg mass at 4.2m/s collides with an 18kg mass at rest. Their common velocity after coalescing is
When an x-ray elastically collides with an electron, there is conservation of
questions.explanation: Elastic collisions conserve both momentum and kinetic energy

questions.question: A 100g body moving at 10m/s collides with a wall and rebounds at 2m/s. Change in momentum is
The force required to make an object of mass m, travelling with velocity v, turn in a circle of radius r is
questions.explanation: Centripetal force F = mv²/r, directed towards the center.

questions.question: The force holding the moon in its orbit around the earth is
questions.explanation: Gravitational force provides the centripetal force.

questions.question: A particle moves in a circular orbit of radius 0.02m at 0.88m/s. Its frequency is
questions.explanation: ω = v/r = 44 rad/s; f = ω/2π ≈ 7 Hz

questions.question: If a whirling ball's string breaks, the ball moves
Uniform circular motion has acceleration that is
questions.explanation: Centripetal acceleration has constant magnitude but changing direction.

questions.question: In uniform circular motion:
questions.explanation: KE is constant; momentum direction changes.

questions.question: A 10g mass rotates at 100 rad/s on a 0.2m blade. Centripetal force is
A 1500kg car takes a 50m radius curve at 40m/s. Centripetal force is
If centripetal force on a 5kg mass is tripled, new speed is
A 1.2m diameter wheel at 1 rev/s has velocity
A 2kg object moves at 10m/s in 4m radius. Centripetal force is
An object in 0.5m radius circle at 1m/s has angular velocity
A 100N body moves at 5m/s in 5m radius. Centripetal force is
A gramophone record reaches 4π rad/s in 5s. Angular acceleration is
In circular motion, maximum speed occurs when
questions.explanation: Speed is maximum at the lowest point due to gravitational acceleration.

questions.question: A wheel makes 90 revolutions in 25s. Frequency is
Which motion is NOT circular? I. Heartbeat II. Vertical spring III. Wheel rotation
questions.explanation: Heartbeat and vertical springs exhibit SHM, not circular motion.

questions.question: A particle performs 30 oscillations in 6s. Angular velocity is
A stone flies off when string breaks because
questions.explanation: Without centripetal force, object moves tangentially (Newton's 1st Law).

questions.question: For a body moving with constant speed in a circular track:
questions.explanation: Centripetal force does no work (always perpendicular to motion).

questions.question: If a pendulum's length increases by 4×, its period increases by
A pendulum (0.6m, T=1.5s) shortened to 0.4m has period
Critical pendulum experiment assumption is
questions.explanation: String length must remain constant for T=2π√(l/g).

questions.question: For 30 oscillations timed at 70s, 72s, 67s, mean period is
Pendulum period depends on
questions.explanation: T = 2π√(l/g) → Independent of mass and amplitude (small angles).

questions.question: In SHM, which are in phase?
questions.explanation: Restoring force and acceleration are always in phase (F = ma).

questions.question: A freely oscillating object follows SHM because
questions.explanation: Defining SHM condition: a ∝ -x (restoring force ∝ displacement).

questions.question: Pendulum (0.4m, T=2s) lengthened to 0.8m has period
A pendulum bob passing lowest point twice per second has length
Pendulum (T=17.0s) shortened by 1.5m gives T=8.5s. Original length was
Which is SHM? I. Heartbeat II. Vertical spring III. Circular motion
questions.explanation: Heartbeat and vertical springs exhibit SHM; circular motion does not.

questions.question: Work done by gravity on pendulum swinging through angle θ is
Correct T vs L graph for pendulum is
Which graphs of pendulum data are linear? I. T vs l II. T² vs l III. logT vs logl
questions.explanation: T² vs l and logT vs logl are linear; T vs l is parabolic.

questions.question: A uniform beam HK of length 10m weighing 200N is supported at both ends. A 1000N man stands at point P. If reactions at H and K are 800N and 400N respectively, the distance HP is _____.
A see-saw has weights 50kg, Xkg, and 15kg at distances 1½m, 1½m, and 2m from pivot. For balance, X is _____.
A lever balances when 1000g hangs 20cm right of fulcrum and 500g hangs 20cm left. The balancing distance x is _____.
A uniform beam PQ (5m, 200N) balances with 800N man at M (QM=2m). Reactions at P and Q are _____ (g=10m/s²).
questions.explanation: ΣF: R₁ + R₂ = 1000N. Moment about P: 5R₂ = 200×2.5 + 800×3 → R₂=580N, R₁=420N

questions.question: A mirror weighing 75N hangs by a cord making 30° with horizontal. The tension is _____.
A uniform metre rule pivoted at 55cm mark balances when 10g hangs at 90cm. The rule's mass is _____.
For the system in equilibrium, tension in string Q is _____.
A uniform rod (50cm) balanced on knife-edge at 55cm requires force F at end to balance. F is _____.
Three coplanar forces in equilibrium must satisfy _____.
questions.explanation: For equilibrium, forces must be concurrent (meet at one point)

questions.question: A uniform beam (10m, 200N) with 14N load at center requires _____ force at end for equilibrium.
Which of the following statements is true of the law of universal gravitation?
options: Any two bodies attract each other with a force which is proportional to the difference of their masses.
Any two bodies attract each other with a force which is inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them.
Any two bodies attract each other with a force which is proportional to the product of their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them.
Any two bodies attract each other with a force which is directly proportional to the square of the distance between them.
questions.explanation: F = Gm₁m₂/r² → Force is proportional to product of masses and inversely proportional to square of distance.

questions.question: The force with which an object is attracted to the earth is called its
questions.explanation: Weight (W=mg) is the gravitational force exerted by Earth.

questions.question: The force experienced by an object of mass 60.0kg in the moon's gravitational field is 1.002 x 10²N. What is the intensity of the gravitational field?
What is the acceleration due to gravity 'g' on the moon, if g is 10ms⁻² on the earth?
A body is projected from the earth's surface with the intention of letting it escape from the earth's gravitational field. What is the minimum escape velocity of the body?

A planet has mass m, and is at a distance r, from the sun. A second planet has mass m₂ = 10m, and is at a distance of r₂=2r, from the sun. Determine the ratio of the gravitational force experienced by the planets.
The force of attraction between two point masses is 10 N when the distance between them is 0.18m. If the distance is reduced to 0.06m, calculate the force.

On which combination does the weight of an object vary on the earth's surface? I. The earth is not spherical but elliptical in shape. II. Variation In latitude and longitude. III. Rotation of the earth on its axis. IV. Variation in the density of the earth.
questions.explanation: All factors affect local gravitational acceleration (g).

questions.question: If the distance between two suspended masses 10kg each is tripled, the gravitational force of attraction between them is reduced by
A satellite is in a parking orbit if its period is
options: less than the period of the earth
more than the period of the earth
equal to the period of the earth
the square of the period of the earth

questions.question: The earth is four times the size of the moon and the acceleration due to gravity on the earth is 80 times that on the moon. The ratio of the mass of the moon to that of the earth is
A force of 200N acts between two objects at a certain distance apart. The value of the force when the distance is halved is
If the radius of the earth is 6.4 x 10⁶m, the escape velocity of a satellite from the earth is
Two spheres of masses 5.0 kg and 10.0 kg are 0.3m apart. Calculate the force of attraction between them.
The values of x, y and z respectively in the expression MˣLʸTᶻ for the universal gravitational constant G are
An object is weighed at different locations on the earth. What will be the right observation?
options: Both the mass and weight vary
The weight is constant while the mass varies
The mass is constant while the weight varies
Both the mass and weight are constant
questions.explanation: Mass is intrinsic; weight depends on local g.

questions.question: A rocket is fired from the earth's surface to a distant planet. By Newton's law of universal gravitation, the force F will
When a brick is taken from the earth's surface to the moon, its mass
questions.explanation: Mass is invariant; weight changes due to different g.

questions.question: Calculate the escape velocity of a satellite launched from the earth's surface if the radius of the earth is 6.4 x 10⁶m
An object of weight 80kg on earth is taken to a planet where the acceleration due to gravity is one-third of its value on earth. The weight of the object on the planet is
questions.explanation: Assuming '80kg' was a typo and should be 80N: W_new = (1/3)W_earth ≈ 26.67 N ≈ 27N.

questions.question: A satellite moves in a circular orbit of radius 4R round the earth. The acceleration of the satellite in terms of g is
A satellite revolving around the earth is kept on its orbit by
The gravitational potential at a point in a gravitational field is the work done in taking a unit mass from
options: a distance to a given point
questions.explanation: By definition: V = W/m (work per unit mass from ∞).

questions.question: In the earth's gravitational field
options: work is done when a force moves its point of application around a closed path
bodies repel themselves when they come close
energy is released when an object is raised above the ground
a body experiences no decrease in its deceleration when its moves freely upwards
questions.explanation: All objects accelerate downward at g ≈ 9.8 m/s² (decelerate upward at same rate).

questions.question: A 500kg car initially at rest accelerates at 5m/s². Its kinetic energy after 4 seconds is?
A freely falling body's kinetic energy at its half-way point is?
questions.explanation: By energy conservation: PE lost = KE gained → mgh/2 = KE

questions.question: Water at a waterfall's base is warmer because?
questions.explanation: Kinetic energy converts to thermal energy (internal energy)

questions.question: The area under a force-distance graph represents?
questions.explanation: Work = Force × Displacement (area under F-d curve)

questions.question: A 50kg man climbs 5m stairs in 5s (g=10m/s²). Power expended is?
Energy conversion sequence when a steam engine powers a lamp?
Work done by a linearly varying force over first 10m is?
A pump lifts 1000kg water 10m in 10s. Its power is?
Device converting sound → electrical energy is?
questions.explanation: Microphone transduces sound waves to electrical signals

questions.question: 40N force gives 0.1m/s² acceleration for 4s. Work done is?
Percentage of PE converted to KE for a 100m fall reaching 20m/s?
questions.explanation: PE = 1000m J, KE = 200m J → 20% conversion (80% lost to friction)

questions.question: Efficiency formula for an energy conversion system?
questions.explanation: Efficiency = Useful Output Energy / Total Input Energy

questions.question: Time for 60kg man to climb 22m at 0.25kW power?
Force provided by engine to maintain speed v with power P?
Work done holding 1kg stone at height h for 50s?
questions.explanation: No displacement → Work = 0 (energy is stored as PE)

questions.question: Work done by semicircular force-displacement graph (radius=12m)?
800N man climbs 15m stairs in 12.5s. Average power output?
Energy changes in hydroelectric power generation?
50kg object dropped from 2m. KE before impact?
Cone in unstable equilibrium has its potential energy?
questions.explanation: PE = mgh increases as height increases in unstable equilibrium

questions.question: Time for mass m to reach speed v with power P?
100g projectile's initial KE at ground level if velocity=20m/s at 10m height?
Height of stairs if 80kg man expends 120W power in 20s?
Power developed by 800kg car reaching 25m/s in 20s?
Total energy of 0.1kg ball thrown upward at 10m/s from 10m tower?
Power change if force and velocity halve simultaneously?
KE of 1kg stone 5m above ground if dropped from 10m?
Work done by triangular force-displacement graph (base=x, height=F)?
KE gained by 4kg mass after 12N force acts for 3s?
Work done by 100N force at 60° over 8m?
Force to stop 80kW car moving at 32m/s?
Work done dragging rice bag with 2N force at 60° over 3m?
Height where PE=KE for object thrown upward at velocity u?
questions.explanation: At h=u²/4g: PE = ¼mgh_max, KE = ¾mgh_max (h_max=u²/2g)

questions.question: Power to lift 750kg cage 90m in 1 minute?
Work to pull 0.1N pendulum bob to 60° angle?
KE of 1.5kg hammer dropped from 20m before impact?
Work done from x=0m to x=80m on force-position graph?
Height for PE to equal KE of 5m/s moving object?
Power of pump lifting 5000kg water 60m in 15min?
KE of 20kg object dropped from 10m before impact?
Nuclear energy ultimately generates?
Power of 400N force moving at 60m/s?
Force from engine power P to maintain speed v?
